message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive anterior drawer test indicates that the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is most likely damaged. The other options would present with different clinical findings, such as pain on the lateral side of the knee with the lateral collateral ligament, or pain behind the knee with the posterior cruciate ligament. The ligamentum patellae is not involved in stability of the knee joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The popping sound, swelling of the knee joint, and positive anterior drawer test suggest damage to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). All other options are not commonly associated with these signs and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The popping sound, swelling of the knee joint, and positive anterior drawer test are all indicative of an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. The other ligaments listed are not typically affected in this type of injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s description of an unstable knee joint with a popping sound and a positive anterior drawer test indicates damage to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The other options would present with different symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The popping sound and positive anterior drawer test suggest that the patient has an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. The other ligaments mentioned in the options are less likely to cause these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive anterior drawer test is indicative of a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), which helps stabilize the knee joint. A tear in the lateral collateral ligament (LCL) would cause pain and instability on the outer side of the knee joint. A tear in the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) would cause difficulty with knee flexion and may lead to instability. The ligamentum patellae helps in the attachment of the patella tendon to the tibia and is not involved in knee stability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of instability and popping sound with a positive anterior drawer test suggests a tear in the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The other ligaments are not typically involved in this mechanism of injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and a positive anterior drawer test suggest a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The other options are less likely based on the presented information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the popping sound and positive anterior drawer test, suggest that the most likely structure damaged is the anterior cruciate ligament. The other ligaments mentioned would have different manifestations on physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The popping sound, swelling, and positive anterior drawer test suggest a likely anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. The lateral collateral ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, and ligamentum patellae are not generally associated with these symptoms.
